posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
A 5 level limit rules out (most) prestige classes. No classes get +6 BAB which would grant one more attack/round. Monk/warriors can have one more attack with +4 BAB because of the monk attack progression with Unarmed and Kama. Dual-wielding, Rapid shot, Flurry of blows, Divine Power and Haste can also add an extra attack. Cleave can add a situational attack.

Low magic usually means that self-buffing characters are best.
Here magic is limited to lvl 3 spells for wizards, clerics and druids, level 2 spells for sorcerers and bards, and level 1 spell(s) for rangers and paladins. Level 3 spells means you can do with 13 or 14 in your casting stat. That makes it possible to have a high strength that gives a better melee presence.

Druids get Wildshape, have an animal companion and can buff with Bull's and Barkskin.
Clerics start to get some buffs and can have Divine Power as a lvl 3 spell with Strength domain.
Bards have a level 3 song and can buff with Ghostly visage and Magic weapon.
Monk/warriors can have 4 attacks with dual Kamas and Flurry active (and a 5th when Cleave kicks in), but the AB will suffer.
Rogues can craft and set pretty good traps. A warrior/rogue can have +4 BAB and 2d6 sneak damage.
A specialist wizard can cast 2 fireballs, buff pretty well and be an all-right melee-mage if the strength is high.
The warrior classes can also do quite well, as long as they can dominate with high strength, full armor, martial weapons and combat feats such as Cleave and Knockdown. They will retain their effectiveness long after the more fancy buffs of other classes have run out.

Edit: As for prestige classes, you can in fact take  one or two levels of Palemaster or one level of  PDK.
